awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Opportunities in Biological and Chemical Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Northeastern University is located in Boston, MA. The program is led by Professors George O'Doherty and Oyindasola Oyelaran. It is funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate. The site supports 10 students for 10 weeks in the summers of 2019-2021. The objective of the program is to provide opportunities for undergraduate students who have a strong interest in chemistry research and a desire to explore this interest further. Students conduct immersive laboratory research under the guidance and mentorship of experienced scientists in the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology. Participants in the program are first-generation college students and students from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the physical sciences. A program goal is to contribute to building a more diverse scientific community. By participating in this program, students not only gain experience in chemical research but also learn valuable professional skills. They broaden their exposure to options for their next step, whether that is entering graduate school or pursuing a career in chemistry or related fields. 

The theme of this REU site is catalysis, broadly defined. The site provides opportunities for students to learn about novel insights and methods of analysis used to understand the chemistry of life as well as to develop innovative, sustainable chemistry.  and tackle fundamental problems that span organic, biological, computational, inorganic, and analytical chemistry. Along with the research, a deeper understanding of these topics is incentivized through short talks, seminars with discussions, and a final oral presentation, coordinated so that all REU site students are exposed to the various scientific questions explored at the site. In addition to the research experience, the students participate in a series of informational and training workshops geared to increase awareness of opportunities in graduate school and careers in chemistry and related fields, and hone skills needed to thrive as a scientist. Through the common theme of catalysis an environment is established where students are engaged in each other?s projects and participate in the critical thinking process that underlies scientific discoveries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In chemistry, catalysis is one of the fundamental concepts that chemists study from basic theory to practice. The unifying theme that guides the Chemistry REU site at Northeastern University in Boston, MA (2019 to 2023) was broadly defined as involving research on chemical catalysis. This theme extended beyond the research training and into mentorship, as the REU program also focused on catalyzing student growth and maturation as a scientist. More specifically, the program aimed to lead students to experience research opportunities and discover future possibilities to advance their careers in the sciences. 

The 27 students who participated in this program were given the opportunity to spend 10 weeks at Northeastern on its Boston campus. During their stay, the students used this time to participate in and focus on executing individual research projects. Although all of the students’ projects were centered on catalysis, the individual projects spanned the various branches of chemistry, including analytical, inorganic, organic, physical, polymer, and theoretical, etc. 

Through a series of formal and informal weekly meetings with their individual research group (i.e., with the Project, PI, graduate student mentor, and other group members), the participants were introduced to a research project and individually guided through the day in/day out working of the project. In an aligned series of formal and informal weekly meetings with their fellow REU participants, the research lessons are shared with the group. This are fundamentally important moments as it gives each participant the crystalizing learning experience that comes from teaching others. 

In a completely aligned effort with the research mission, the REU program is designed to help catalyze the participants’ growth as chemical scientists. Through the same group and individualized meetings, the 27 REU participants were exposed to a research environment that demonstrated the various career opportunities the chemical sciences offer. The career and life lessons for the REU students began with their individual interactions with their PI and student mentor. These lessons were buttressed through research and social interactions with other members of their research group. Through these formal and informal relationships, they learned how to fit into a larger research project, and how their research experience could help prepare them for a future in the sciences. These themes were further reinforced with two group outings to local companies (e.g., Merck Research Laboratories and Eisai Center for Genetics Guided Dementia Discovery) in the greater Boston area. In addition, the REU participants attended research seminars given by visiting scientists from local, national, and international industrial and academic institutions. Finally at the end of the 10-week program, the students present their research results to the department in a daylong seminar.
